par2.content: other words for another paragraph, which would be paragraph 2.

pieces1.definition: Non-living structures that contain genetic material, which need a host to reproduce.
A single-celled organism that has no nucleus to contain its genetic material and no organelles.
Single or multi-cellular organisms whose cells have a nucleus containing genetic material as well as other organelles.

pieces1.hint: Examples include: plants, animals, fungi, and protists.

pieces1.definition: Organelle within eukaryotes that contains genetic material for the cell.

pieces1.hint: This is the 'brain' of the cell because it stores the 'blueprints' or instructions.

pieces1.definition: The protein coating of a virus that encloses the genetic material.

pieces1.hint: This is not a cell membrane and is found on viruses.

pieces2.definition: Eukaryotic cells, which do NOT contain cell walls or chloroplasts, but do contain centrioles.

pieces2.hint: Type of eukaryotic cells that make up humans!

pieces2.definition: Eukaryotic cells surrounded by cell walls, which DO contain chloroplasts, and a large central vacuole.

pieces2.hint: These type of eukaryotic cells make up the grass in your lawn.

pieces2.definition: Made up of at least one cell, interact with the environment, can grow and reproduce.

pieces2.hint: This category includes us, plants, and animals. aka biotic things.

pieces2.definition: Objects that do not meet the requirements of life such as being made up of one or more cells, growing and reproducing.

pieces2.hint: The include things like viruses, rocks, water, sunlight. aka Abiotic factors.

pieces2.definition: Membrane-bound structures found inside eukaryotic cells. They allow eukaryotes to become complex living organisms.

pieces2.hint: Examples include: nucleus, mitochondria, chloroplast, golgi complex, rough and smooth ER
